awd_titl_txt: Transient Optical Nonlinearities Engendered by Femtosecond Laser Filamentation in Gases
awd_abstract_narration:
Atomic and molecular processes initiated and controlled by intense, ultrashort laser pulses are a subject of steadily growing interest in plasma science and related technology. The laser-induced ionization and excitation of individual atoms and molecules beget in turn various nonlinear optical phenomena in the plasma medium. One such phenomenon, laser filamentation, is enabled by self-focusing of the laser beam, which results in a drastic contraction of the laser pulse and generation of an extended filament at a controllable stand-off distance. Partially ionized plasma is left in the wake of the filamenting laser pulse; it can be probed by subsequent laser pulses and is open to various practical applications. This theoretical research addresses a new realm of transient nonlinear optics in evolving filament-wake channels; it explores longer-lasting optical consequences of strong-field ionization occurring in a relatively dense plasma. The research will advance broader understanding of means to control strong-field light-matter interaction on a microscopic scale. It also directly addresses recent developments of filament-based, multiplex methods of remote detection of complex mixtures, which is a challenge with many technological applications. It is related to control of filamentation dynamics with the aim of remote lasing in the atmosphere, and to developing new sources of attosecond and X-ray pulses.

This research concerns the interrelated dynamics of ions, energetic free electrons, and excited neutrals in wake channels of femtosecond laser filaments, as well as the interaction of the evolving system with probe laser pulses. The expected outcomes will form a basis for effective control of filament-wake nonlinear optical effects. The task will be addressed using a combination of ab initio calculations for nonlinear response of individual ions, kinetic modeling of inhomogeneous ionized-gas medium evolution, and density matrix calculations for probe laser coupling with the medium. The objectives include:
1) developing predictive models of the evolution of ion density profiles and molecular/atomic excitation in filament wake channels and ionization gratings, which is driven by competing processes of impact ionization, impact electronic excitation of neutrals and ions, dissociative recombination, vibrational excitation, and elastic scattering; 
2) calculating dynamic polarizability and hyperpolarizability coefficients of ions in the wake of the ionizing laser pulse (when perturbative approaches become applicable) by implementing the auxiliary-field approach and ab initio calculations, and applying the results to obtain evolving spatial profiles of dynamic quadratic and quartic nonlinear refractive indices in filament wake channels; and
3) predicting outcomes of nonlinear interactions of probe laser pulses with the wake channels, including two-beam coupling mediated by ionization gratings, ionic rotational revivals, and controllable spatial-spectral patterns of dynamic Rabi sideband emission. 
The expected results will be applied to experiments on ionization-related polarization rotation, rotational-revival spectroscopy, and dynamic Rabi sidebands in filament wake channels at the Center for Advanced Photonics Research (CAPR) at Temple University. Further, the ionization-specific nonlinear effects are related to recent experiments on bright higher harmonic generation (up to X-rays) in highly ionized gases and on igniter-heater processes in filament wake channels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the process of femtosecond laser filamentation in a gas medium, an intense laser pulse self-focuses and causes ionization of the gas atoms/molecules. A channel of partially ionized, nonequilibrium plasma is left in the pulse wake, begetting nonlinear optical phenomena and the following gas dynamics. Our research ventured into a largely unexplored area of nascent collective effects in these emerging laser-generated plasmas. It addresses transitional regime in which the electrons released by the strong-field ionization become interacting with neighbor atoms but do not yet cause avalanche processes. This happens when the length of electron excursions in the oscillating laser field exceeds the interatomic distances. As a representative system, we considered high-pressure argon gas.

We developed a unified theoretical description of the medium excitation during the femtosecond pulse and of the picosecond-scale evolution after the pulse. During the pulse, the released electrons are driven by the oscillating laser field, colliding with neighboring neutral atoms; this is described by a kinetic model. In the pulse wake, the system evolves in the framework of diffusion-reaction equations, making for the spatio-temporal dependences of ionic and excited-atom densities and the built-in electric field, which are available for linear and nonlinear light-scattering experiments.

The complex interplay of competing collisional processes during the pulse determines the sensitivity of the plasma composition to the pulse envelope shape. We investigated these control effects by considering several families of pulses and have shown that asymmetric forward-skewed envelopes result in considerably higher values of the crucial ratio of excited- and ionized-atom densities.

Toward generation of wake channels microscopically structured by design, we studied processes in the crossing area of two laser beams, when interference leads to inhomogeneous ionization and excitation around the peak intensity lines. The build-up of the grating-like ionic and excited-atom density patterns depends on the beam crossing angle, the spatial and temporal profiles of the two pulses, and the interpulse phase delay.

As massive presence of excited atoms is a hallmark of wake channels in dense gases, we considered a nonlinear optical effect linked to these excited atoms: the Rabi sideband radiation. This phenomenon is invoked by a picosecond probe laser pulse, which couples to dipole transitions in the excited states manifold of argon. The Rabi cycling in these effective two-state systems results in coherent sideband emission around the 800 nm carrier wavelength. We obtained the characteristic fringe patterns of spectral and spatial interference in the sideband radiation, which are indicative of the grating-like distribution of the excited-atom density in the wake channel.

In molecular gases, an important wake-channel optical nonlinearity is the periodically recurring birefringence related to molecular alignment. We discovered a new alignment mode, which is mediated by transient nonadiabatic charge redistribution (TNCR). When the electrons do not follow the laser field oscillations, but rather exhibit prolong concentration on one side of the molecule, this drastically modifies the rotational wavepacket formation and the induced transient birefringence pattern. We obtained the TNCR-mediated rotational wavepackets in model molecules and demonstrated the role of many-body effects in the cumulative torque.

Our findings on the control of transient optical nonlinearities in filament wake channels warrant direct experimental verification and have potential technological and military applications. The predicted few-line excitation gratings at laser beam crossings in dense gases can be produced controllably, at desired positions in the gas, number of lines, and spatial parity. These grating characteristics are observable in experiments, as they are manifested in the spatial-spectral interference patterns of the Rabi sideband radiation invoked by a probe laser pulse. Further, analogs of the investigated dense-gas processes are expected to be found in atmospheric-pressure gases interacting with laser pulses that have longer carrier wavelengths (~ 4 micrometers), which recently become available for strong-field applications.

The outcomes of our research are directly linked to experiments at the Center for Advanced Photonics Research (CAPR) at Temple University. These experiments concern remote detection and identification of chemical compounds in atmosphere enabled by intense, broadband laser pulses. Another area of application is the remote control of gas-phase chemical reactions via tailored femtosecond laser pulses. Here, our results are used to assist the chemical experiments on laser-induced production of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species in dry and wet air.

The CAPR activities directly address industrial, military, and societal needs. They aim at new methods for remote detection and classification of explosives, radioactive materials, and tissue phenotypes. The development of novel detection methods for complex mixtures is a challenge with many other applications that are critically important for current societal needs. Filament-based, multiplex detection methods will be of essential help for analysis of smokestack effluent, environmental monitoring (lakes, river, land) where chemical distributions are sought, coatings analysis, combinatorial synthesis of pharmaceuticals, and biomedical tracking, for example. We anticipate that our contribution to these investigations will ultimately have a significant impact in these areas.
